title: Lesson 17: Animal Tissues - Nervous Tissue and the Neuron
content:
Lesson 17: Animal Tissues - Nervous Tissue and the Neuron

The Body's High-Speed Communication Network

If you accidentally touch a hot pan, you pull your hand away in a fraction of a second, often before you even feel the pain. How does the message "DANGER, HOT!" travel from your finger to your brain and back to your arm muscles so incredibly fast?

This high-speed communication is managed by a remarkable tissue that acts like the body's own internet. Let's explore Nervous Tissue.

The Body's Command and Control Center

All cells in our body have the ability to respond to stimuli, but the cells of Nervous Tissue are highly specialized for this job. They are designed to be stimulated and then transmit that stimulus very rapidly from one place to another within the body.

This tissue makes up the entire nervous system: the brain, the spinal cord, and all the nerves that branch out to every part of your body. It is the master tissue responsible for control and coordination.

The Neuron: The Building Block of the Nervous System

The specialized cells that make up nervous tissue are called neurons (or nerve cells). Each neuron is like a tiny, living electrical wire, designed to carry a message. A typical neuron has three main parts.

1. Cell Body (or Cyton)

This is the main part of the cell, containing the nucleus and cytoplasm. It's the neuron's control center.

2. Dendrites

These are the short, branched, hair-like parts that arise from the cell body. They act like antennas, receiving signals from other neurons.

3. Axon and Nerve Ending

Each neuron usually has a single, long "cable" called the axon, which transmits the signal away from the cell body. The end of the axon branches out into nerve endings, which pass the signal on to the next cell.

Sending a Message: The Nerve Impulse

The signal that passes along a neuron is a tiny electrical wave called a nerve impulse. This impulse travels in one direction only, like a high-speed relay race:

Dendrites (Receive) Cell Body Axon (Transmit) Nerve Ending (Pass On)

Many nerve fibres (axons) are often bundled together by connective tissue to form a nerve, just like many thin copper wires are bundled together to form a thick electrical cable.

Nervous Tissue: The Key Concepts

The Tissue

Nervous tissue forms the brain, spinal cord, and nerves. Its job is control and communication.

The Cell (Neuron)

Made of dendrites (receivers), a cell body, and an axon (transmitter).

The Signal

A rapid electrical signal called a nerve impulse travels along the neuron to transmit information.
questions:
Lesson 17: Questions and Answers

1. What is the special ability of the cells of nervous tissue?

The cells of nervous tissue are highly specialized to be stimulated and to transmit the stimulus (signal) very rapidly from one place to another within the body.

2. Draw a diagram of a neuron and label its three main parts.

Here is a labeled diagram of a neuron (nerve cell):

The three main parts are the Cell Body, Dendrites, and the Axon.

3. What is a nerve impulse?

A nerve impulse is the signal that passes along a nerve fibre (the axon). It is a tiny electrical wave that carries information from one part of the body to another.

4. What is the function of dendrites and the axon in a neuron?

  • Dendrites: These are short, branched extensions that act like antennas. Their function is to receive signals from other neurons and pass them towards the cell body.
  • Axon: This is a single, long fibre. Its function is to transmit the nerve impulse away from the cell body to the next neuron or to a muscle cell.

5. What is the difference between a neuron and a nerve?

Step 1: Define a Neuron.
A neuron is a single nerve cell.

Step 2: Define a Nerve.
A nerve is a bundle of many nerve fibres (axons) bound together by connective tissue.

Analogy: A single neuron is like one thin copper wire. A nerve is like a thick electrical cable made of hundreds of those thin wires bundled together.

6. What parts of the human body are composed of nervous tissue?

The brain, spinal cord, and all the nerves in the body are composed of nervous tissue.

7. In which direction does a nerve impulse travel through a neuron?

A nerve impulse is a one-way signal. It is received by the dendrites, passes through the cell body, travels down the long axon, and is passed on from the nerve endings.

Dendrite Cell Body Axon

8. True or False: "An individual nerve cell can be up to a metre long."

True.

Reason: The axon of a single neuron can be very long. For example, a neuron that controls your toe muscle has its cell body in your lower spinal cord, and its axon extends all the way down your leg to your foot, which can easily be a metre long.

9. The functional combination of which two tissues is fundamental to most animals for rapid response to stimuli?

The functional combination of Nervous tissue and Muscular tissue is fundamental to most animals.

Explanation: Nervous tissue rapidly transmits the signal (the decision to act), and muscular tissue receives that signal and carries out the physical action (movement).

10. What are the two main parts that make up the cell body of a neuron?

The cell body consists of the nucleus and the cytoplasm.
exercises:
Lesson 17: Exercises

Exercise 1: The Signal's Path

The diagram shows the parts of a neuron, but they are in the wrong order for transmitting a signal. Arrange the parts (A, B, C, D) in the correct sequence that a nerve impulse follows.

A. Axon
B. Nerve Ending
C. Cell Body
D. Dendrite

The correct sequence is:

D. Dendrite C. Cell Body A. Axon B. Nerve Ending

Explanation: The dendrite receives the signal, which then passes through the cell body and travels down the long axon to the nerve ending, where it's passed on to the next cell.

Exercise 2: Job Description Match

Match the part of the neuron in Column A to its correct job description in Column B.

Column A (Neuron Part)

  • 1. Axon
  • 2. Cell Body
  • 3. Dendrite

Column B (Job Description)

  • A. Contains the nucleus and cytoplasm.
  • B. Receives signals from other neurons.
  • C. The long fibre that transmits the signal away.

Correct Matches:

  • 1. Axon matches with C. The long fibre that transmits the signal away.
  • 2. Cell Body matches with A. Contains the nucleus and cytoplasm.
  • 3. Dendrite matches with B. Receives signals from other neurons.

Exercise 3: Critical Thinking - A Broken Wire

A person suffers an injury that damages the nerves in their arm. They find that they can still feel a pinprick on their finger, but they cannot move their fingers to pull away. Which part of the nervous pathway is likely damaged?

The pathway sending signals FROM the brain TO the muscle is likely damaged.

Explanation: Feeling the pinprick means the sensory neurons (carrying the "pain" signal TO the brain) are working. The inability to move the fingers means the motor neurons (carrying the "move" command FROM the brain) are damaged and cannot deliver the nerve impulse to the muscle tissue.

Exercise 4: The Relay Race

In the relay race of the nervous system, which part of Neuron A passes the "baton" (nerve impulse) to which part of Neuron B?

Answer:

The nerve ending of Neuron A passes the impulse to the dendrite of Neuron B.

Exercise 5: What Am I?

Identify the term based on its description.

  • I am a bundle of nerve fibres bound together by connective tissue.
  • I am the electrical signal that travels along a neuron.
  • I am a single, specialized cell that makes up nervous tissue.
  • Nerve
  • Nerve Impulse
  • Neuron (or Nerve Cell)

Exercise 6: True or False?

Read the statements below. State if they are true or false and correct the false statement.

  • A neuron can have many axons but only one dendrite.
  • All cells in the body can transmit nerve impulses.
  • False. A neuron usually has one axon and many dendrites.
  • False. Only the specialized cells of nervous tissue (neurons) can transmit nerve impulses.
intros:
Lesson 17: Animal Tissues - Nervous Tissue and the Neuron

Meet the body's high-speed internet—the tissue that sends messages in milliseconds to control every thought and action!

Intro 1: The Body's Internet

How can a thought that starts in your brain make your toe wiggle almost instantly?

Your body has its own biological internet—the Nervous System. This entire system, including the brain, spinal cord, and all your nerves, is built from Nervous Tissue. The "cables" of this internet are highly specialized cells called neurons.

These neurons are designed to transmit information at incredible speeds. The message itself is a tiny electrical signal called a nerve impulse. It zips along the neuron from one end of the body to the other, allowing your brain to communicate with and control every part of you almost instantaneously.

Nervous tissue is the body's information superhighway, powered by living, lightning-fast wires.

Intro 2: The Command Center

How does the "CEO" in your head send urgent memos to every department in your body?

It uses a dedicated, high-speed communication network. Your brain, spinal cord, and all the nerves branching out from them form your body's command and control system. This entire network is built from one special tissue: Nervous Tissue.

The fundamental units of this tissue are the neurons, or nerve cells. These cells are master communicators. They are designed to respond to stimuli (like a thought or a touch) and transmit that information as an electrical signal, called a nerve impulse, to other parts of the body. This allows the "CEO" (your brain) to manage everything from a deliberate action like kicking a ball to an automatic one like breathing.

Nervous tissue is the body's ultimate management and communication system.

Intro 3: The Domino Effect

You step on a sharp object, and your foot jerks up instantly. How does the "pain" signal travel so fast from your foot to your brain and back to your leg muscle?

It travels like a chain reaction of falling dominoes! The tissue responsible for this high-speed messaging is Nervous Tissue. It's built from long cells called neurons that are lined up end-to-end.

When you step on the sharp object, the first neuron "domino" is triggered. It passes an electrical signal, the nerve impulse, to the next neuron, which passes it to the next, and so on, all the way to your brain and back down to your leg muscle in a fraction of a second. This rapid transmission allows for the lightning-fast reflexes that are essential for survival.

Like a row of dominoes, nervous tissue passes signals with incredible speed and precision.

Intro 4: The Living Wire

To send electricity, you need a wire with specific parts. What would a "living wire" look like?


(Input/Receiver) Cell Body
(Processing Unit) Axon (The Long Cable) Nerve Endings
(Output/Transmitter)

It would look like a neuron, the amazing cell that makes up all Nervous Tissue. A neuron is perfectly designed to carry electrical signals, called nerve impulses. It has three main parts.

The dendrites are short, branched "receivers" that pick up signals from other cells. The cell body is the "processing unit" containing the nucleus. And the axon is the single, long "cable" that carries the signal away from the cell body. Some axons can be incredibly long—up to a metre—to carry signals all the way from your spinal cord to your foot!

A neuron is a perfectly designed biological wire, complete with a receiver, processor, and transmitter.

Intro 5: The Ultimate Relay Race

How is a message passed in a relay race? One runner passes the baton to the next. How does your body do it with nerve signals?

It's almost the exact same principle! Your body's communication network, the Nervous Tissue, is made of a chain of cells called neurons.

A signal, called a nerve impulse, is like the relay baton. It travels down the long axon of the first neuron (the first runner). At the very end, the nerve endings of this neuron act like an outstretched hand, passing the "baton" across a tiny gap to the dendrites of the next neuron (the next runner). This process repeats, allowing the signal to be passed rapidly along a chain of nerve cells to its destination.

Nervous tissue runs the body's fastest relay race, passing signals from cell to cell.
summary:
Lesson 17 Summary: Nervous Tissue

The Body's Communication System for Exam Preparation

1. The Tissue of Control and Communication

  • Primary Function: Cells are highly specialized to respond to stimuli and transmit signals (nerve impulses) rapidly from one place to another.
  • Locations: Composes the brain, spinal cord, and nerves.
  • Nerve: A nerve is a bundle of nerve fibres (axons) held together by connective tissue.

2. The Neuron: The Structural and Functional Unit

Cell Body (Cyton)

Contains the nucleus and cytoplasm; the main metabolic center.

Dendrites

Short, branched, hair-like extensions that receive signals from other neurons.

Axon

A single, long fibre that transmits the signal away from the cell body. Can be up to a metre long.

Nerve Ending

The end of the axon, which passes the impulse to the next neuron or to a muscle/gland.
